This is evident in many Caribbean nations, including Antigua and Barbuda, where the overall internet usage rate is relatively high, and the gender parity score is close to 1.0, signalling near equality in access between men and women (ITU, 2023). SIDS, including Antigua and Barbuda, are unique in that they tend to have a higher gender parity score compared to other low- income or less developed regions. While global averages show men using the internet more than women (70% men vs. 65% women), small island nations have a parity score close to 0.97, and in some cases, women even outnumber men in internet usage (ITU, 2023). Promoting and implementing the UNESCO Recommendation on AI Ethics. In view of the norms contained in the 1988 Federal Constitution, particularly with regard to the promotion of peace, equality, development, democracy and human rights, in all their forms and for all peoples, whether Brazilian or foreign, it is recommended that the Brazilian government continue its efforts to effectively implement the UNESCO Recommendation, with an emphasis on promoting ethics, transparency and respect for human rights in the development and use of AI. In addition, it is recommended to the National Justice Council to incorporate the UNESCO Recommendation on AI Ethics in the update of Resolution No. 332/2020. recommendations.text: REGULATION This section includes recommendations based on the gaps identified in the legal section of the RAM, the discussions held with different stakeholders during the participatory sessions, and the legal initiatives currently being discussed in Chile. The recommendations include both legal and regulatory actions for the short and medium term, including the responsible institutions for their implementation. Assign urgency to the updating of the Personal Data Protection Law and the Cybersecurity and Information Critical Infrastructure Bill The safeguarding of personal data is regarded as a fundamental element in ensuring the effective adherence to the principles and values outlined in UNESCO’s Recommendations. The diagnostic process conducted during the implementation of the RAM raised concerns about the outdated nature of Chile’s current legislation concerning the protection of personal data. Furthermore, ensuring a secure digital ecosystem for the development and ethical use of AI requires addressing cybersecurity threats and treating information as a critical infrastructure. In this regard, two pieces of legislation currently being discussed in parliament should be given urgent priority. The first is the bill that regulates the protection and processing of personal data and creates the Personal Data Protection Agency (bulletins 11144-07 and 11092-07, currently in its third constitutional process). Chile has signed international commitments to update this law, which is vital for ensuring an adequate protection of people’s rights against potential risks in digital environments. The second legislation is the Framework Law on Cybersecurity and Critical Information Infrastructure (bulletin 14847-06, in the second constitutional process), which creates the National Cybersecurity Agency with regulatory, supervisory and sanctioning powers for state agencies and private institutions. Example cases of Sandboxes The OECD (2023c) defines regulatory sandboxes as a specific regulatory experimentation tool in which flexibility or waivers are set in place for firms to test new systems with reduced requirements. Sandboxes include mechanisms to protect users and, since they closely connect firms and officials from governing bodies, can also inform policy development. Some characteristics of sandboxes are their temporary nature, trial-and-error approach and collaboration between multiple stakeholders. However, there is no one specific definition nor shape that sandboxes take since they are very context-dependent. Some examples of sandboxes that can inform and inspire the Chilean case are: • Brazil: Recently, the Brazilian National Data Protection Authority opened a call for proposals to create a regulatory sandbox to increase algorithmic transparency, foster AI responsible innovation and inform AI regulation (ANPD, 2023). • Colombia: The government created a supervised space where firms can develop AI tools that are privacy preserving. The sandbox provides a collaborative environment which facilitates testing tools to achieve privacy standards (SIC, 2021). • Korea: A group of four ministries related to economy, science and technology created a sandbox that can provide regulatory waivers to test products, services and business models. While tests are conducted, the data informs government regulation. Since 2019, the sandboxes expanded into special regulation-free zones for some specific sectors and applications (Fintech Center Korea, 2023). recommendations.text: Utilise soft regulations and guidelines for the adoption of ethical principles in AI systems Since changing existing laws often require lengthy discussions, it is recommended to explore the use of soft-regulations such as the use of rules and directives that can guide the public and private sector in the use of ethical principles in AI systems. Such principles include: proportionality, safety and protection, equity and non-discrimination, human oversight and decision-making, transparency and explainability, as well as accountability and responsibility. Drawing from successful national precedents, it is suggested to contemplate the use of instruments such as presidential guidelines to steer the adoption of ethical principles in the deployment of AI systems within government agencies. The establishment of these guidelines within the public sector could serve as a valuable model for applying these principles across various domains. To promote the sharing of knowledge and the dissemination of lessons learned during its implementation, it is recommended to systematically document and publicise both the process and the outcomes of this experience. Institutional Framework: Governing AI in Curaçao To effectively regulate and promote AI development, it is recommended that Curaçao organize its AI Oversight across ministries. The agencies responsible will coordinate the oversight on policy implementation, regulatory compliance, and AI funding programs. The initiative will facilitate collaboration between government ministries, universities, private sector partners, and international organizations to ensure that AI development aligns with national economic goals and ethical standards. The AI Oversight should contain an Ethics Committee tasked with conducting AI audits, risk assessments, and ethical evaluations. This Committee will monitor AI systems in critical sectors such as finance, healthcare, and public administration, ensuring that they comply with ethical guidelines. The committee will also develop guidelines on AI fairness, bias detection, and accountability, protecting citizens from potential AI-related harms. To facilitate data-driven AI policymaking, Curaçao will establish an AI Policy Laboratory to help coordinate and assist integrated policy development. This laboratory will collect and analyze data on AI adoption trends, market impact, and research progress. Utilization of real-time data will enable policymakers to make informed decisions about AI regulation, funding priorities, and investment strategies. At the local level, the government can designate AI liaisons in neighborhood centers to oversee AI adoption in smart initiatives, public transportation, and urban planning. These efforts will ensure that AI-driven solutions are tailored to local needs and integrated into public services efficiently. Recommendations – Institutional Framework: Governing AI in Curaçao

keyFindings: Evaluating AI strategies and their implementation is an ongoing challenge.
The Dominican Republic used the first RAM’s results to hone the ENIA’s draft and incorporated its recommendation of using it to complement the existing indicators to evaluate the ENIA.
The RAM is a comprehensive evaluation, and most (if not all) countries will find gaps in their ecosystems when applying it.
Using the results to develop and prioritize policies to fill the gaps, as the Dominican Republic did, reduces resistance among government stakeholders.
Despite identifying relevant gaps, the Dominican Republic RAM was analyzed alongside the ENIA, which proved helpful in streamlining its acceptance and further embracing it for future evaluation.

recommendations.text: Priority: high Develop policies on open data and data sharing Policies on open data and data sharing should be developed, and campaigns to change mindsets in this regard should be initiated, to avoid a siloed working culture and promote collaborative, data- driven functioning. This could lead to increased availability of Maldives-specific AI training data (in Dhivehi and including culturally specific datasets) through standardized open-source repositories, for example, while protecting data privacy with a comprehensive data protection law. This law should be aligned with international standards to safeguard personal data and enhance public trust in AI technologies. UNESCO has published guidelines for Member States on how to open their data in a sustainable manner, how to build capacities in this regard, and how to build an open-data-driven culture (UNESCO, 2023b). Data-sharing initiatives, such as those by the Maldives Bureau of Statistics or the planned Data Sharing Platform for Climate Action (D4DInsights, 2025) could also lay the groundwork for AI systems.

recommendations.title: Priority
recommendations.text: Priority: high Create specific AI procurement guidelines Specific guidelines for the procurement of AI technologies within public sector projects should be formulated to ensure transparency, cybersecurity, fairness and adherence to ethical standards. To mitigate the risks of biased algorithms and security vulnerabilities, clear policies must be established to regulate the procurement of AI systems. These policies should outline necessary criteria for purchasing AI systems, including requirements for ethical compliance, technical robustness and alignment with national AI goals and standards. The policies should specifically include accessibility requirements for persons with disabilities. The accessibility should be tested and endorsed by persons with disabilities. By setting these standards, the government can ensure that AI systems are developed with ethical considerations in mind. A national-level coordinating initiative can harmonize sector-specific AI procurement needs and policies by establishing standardized guidelines and frameworks. This could include developing model contracts and procurement templates. These policies should also include mechanisms for the evaluation and oversight of contracted AI systems, with regular assessments to guarantee compliance with established guidelines. This allows for the continuous improvement of AI systems and their adaptation to evolving standards and societal needs, ensuring that AI systems remain aligned with government objectives.

recommendations.title: Priority
recommendations.text: Priority: medium 33 Enhance cybersecurity regulations to protect AI systems A bill on cybersecurity to enhance the scope of the National Cyber Security Agency should be enacted, with a view to ensuring the integrity and security of data used in AI applications. Given Maldives’ very low ranking in terms of cybersecurity, it is crucial to protect AI systems from vulnerabilities and threats, including against critical infrastructure. AI systems rely on vast amounts of data, making them vulnerable to data breaches and cyberattacks. If compromised, AI systems can be manipulated to produce biased or incorrect results, leading to harmful consequences for users of these systems. Cybersecurity measures like encryption and secure authentication can help prevent such threats. Effective cybersecurity also ensures the integrity and reliability of AI decision-making processes. By protecting AI systems, cybersecurity helps maintain trust in these technologies and prevents potential harm.

Given the digital divide between the Greater Male' region and other islands, it will be critical that representatives from these islands are members of the advisory council. Also, persons with disabilities should be represented in the advisory council. The advisory council would facilitate dialogue among stakeholders, identify emerging AI trends and issues, and provide recommendations on how to address them. Additionally, the council could help ensure that AI policies align with Maldivian national values and priorities. It could also foster international collaboration and knowledge-sharing on AI governance.

recommendations.title: Priority
recommendations.text: Priority: high 34 Establish an AI Centre of Excellence to foster collaborations and partnerships Maldives might consider establishing an AI Centre of Excellence to serve as a hub for innovation and research and development in AI. This centre would bring together experts from academia, industry and government to collaborate on AI projects and to drive innovation. The centre could learn from the existing Centre of Excellence for Public Safety67 and could be affiliated with Maldives National University. An AI Centre of Excellence would also provide training and capacity-building programmes, fostering a skilled workforce and promoting a culture of AI-driven innovation in Maldives. These activities could include partnerships with government entities and academic institutions to promote research and the sharing of best practices in AI. Moreover, an AI Centre of Excellence could host incubators, accelerators and co-working spaces for AI start-ups. International collaboration would be crucial for such a centre as international partnerships could enable functions that Maldives does not necessarily have the capacity or resources to undertake, such as auditing and testing. This would also allow the products of Maldives to align with international standards, paving the way for international market access.

recommendations.title: Priority
recommendations.text: Priority: medium Develop sector-specific AI task forces AI task forces should be formed within key sectors (e.g. healthcare, education, environment, finance and tourism) so that their experienced personnel can harness the full potential of AI by tailoring AI strategies to address the challenges and opportunities unique to their fields. These task forces could identify sector-specific AI applications, develop guidelines for responsible adoption and ensure that AI solutions are aligned with the sector’s goals and values. In healthcare, for example, AI-powered diagnostic tools can analyse medical images to help doctors detect diseases earlier and more accurately. In education, AI-driven adaptive learning systems can tailor educational content to individual students’ needs, abilities and learning styles. For the environment, AI-powered monitoring systems can analyse satellite imagery and sensor data to track rising sea-levels, predict coastal erosion and identify areas most vulnerable to climate change, enabling proactive conservation efforts. In finance, AI-based fraud-detection systems can analyse transaction patterns to identify and prevent fraudulent activities, reducing financial losses and protecting customers. In the tourism sector, AI-powered chatbots can provide personalized travel recommendations, offer real- time booking assistance and help visitors plan their trips to Maldives.

recommendations.text: Priority: medium Preserve the cultural diversity and heritage of Maldives through AI A dedicated advisory board of experts within the current institutional framework should be created to focus on preserving the unique cultural identity and heritage of Maldives, using AI. As stated in 67 https://www.police.gov.mv/media/news/22730 35 the UNESCO Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence, ‘Member States are encouraged to leverage AI systems to preserve, promote and manage cultural heritage. This can be achieved by incorporating AI into educational programs and ensuring a participatory approach that involves institutions and the public. Additionally, Member States should assess the cultural impact of AI systems, particularly natural language processing applications, on human language and expression. This assessment should inform strategies that maximize the benefits of AI while addressing negative implications, such as the potential disappearance of endangered languages and cultural variations’ (UNESCO, 2022). This involves integrating local cultural content into AI training datasets to ensure that AI systems reflect and respect the cultural diversity of Maldives. This can be facilitated by community- driven AI projects that aim to document, preserve and promote local cultural practices and heritage, for which the participation of women, the elderly and people who live on islands beyond the Greater Male' region is essential.

These campaigns could include workshops, seminars and online resources to educate the public about AI’s capabilities, limitations and potential impacts on society. By promoting a nuanced understanding of AI, such campaigns can help alleviate concerns and misconceptions, fostering a more informed and balanced public discourse. Additionally, the campaigns can highlight the opportunities and benefits of AI, such as improved healthcare, education and preservation of cultural heritage, and environmental conservation, as well as economic growth, especially related to tourism. By promoting diversity and inclusion, such campaigns can also help create a more equitable and vibrant AI ecosystem in Maldives.

recommendations.text: Priority: high Increase the number of STEM and AI graduates, especially females Science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and AI-related subjects should occupy an important place in schools from an early stage. This could spark students’ interest, including that of young girls, in these fields and prepare them for further studies. Scholarships and financial incentives could be offered to students pursuing STEM and AI-related degrees, making these fields more attractive and accessible. Partnerships with international universities and institutions could also provide opportunities for Maldivian students to study abroad and gain exposure to cutting-edge technologies. recommendations.text: WAY FORWARD Malaysia is strategically advancing its position to harness Artificial Intelligence (AI) as a transformative driver of national development. With a clear vision to evolve into a high- income, innovation-driven digital economy, the government has adopted a comprehensive and ethical approach to AI through the National AI Roadmap (AI-RMap) 2021–2025. Aligned with UNESCO’s Recommendation on the Ethics of AI, the roadmap integrates key national strategies including the Malaysia Digital Economy Blueprint, DSTIN 2021–2030, and the 10- 10 MySTIE Framework. Moving forward, the successful implementation of Malaysia’s AI agenda will hinge on reinforcing the principles of Responsible AI, fairness, safety, privacy, inclusiveness, transparency, accountability, and human-centricity as articulated in the National Guidelines on AI Governance and Ethics (AIGE). These voluntary guidelines should evolve into enforceable standards, ensuring ethical AI adoption across sectors. Institutionally, the establishment of the National AI Office (NAIO) in December 2024 provides the governance structure needed to transition Malaysia from an AI user to a competitive AI innovator. NAIO must strengthen coordination among government, industry, academia, and civil society to scale responsible AI solutions nationwide. To achieve this, Malaysia must focus on five critical areas: 1. Regulatory and Ethical Strengthening: Update existing legislation, develop sector-specific policies, and implement robust compliance mechanisms to ensure AI systems align with national values and international ethical standards. 2. Capability Building & Talent Development: Expand digital and AI literacy across the public sector, establish dedicated AI governance roles, and grow localized datasets that reflect Malaysia’s unique social and cultural contexts. recommendations.text: Adopt a national agenda on AI: • Mozambique must engage in a national debate that seeks to adopt an agenda on priorities to be followed in the field of AI and to define criteria for decisions on whether to adopt different services or technologies that have AI as a central tool. Responsible Institutions: MCTES Timeframe: 2024-2025

recommendations.title: Foster integration of ethical principles in the realm of AI
recommendations.text: Foster integration of ethical principles in the realm of AI: • AI development must align with the country’s cultural values and norms. This approach promotes sensitivity to local perspectives, fostering technology that is respectful and inclusive of Mozambican cultural diversity. Integrating ethical principles involves mitigating biases and discriminatory practices in AI algorithms. Mozambique can strive for fairness in AI applications, avoiding the reinforcement of existing social inequalities and ensuring that AI systems treat all individuals equitably. Ethical integration involves actively engaging various stakeholders, including communities, experts, and organizations. This collaborative approach ensures that diverse perspectives are considered, making AI development more inclusive, reflective of societal needs, and less likely to unintentionally marginalize certain groups. In addition, the country’s 36 existing human rights standards form a vital normative foundation for AI ethics principles, including the role for the National Human Rights Commission of Mozambique. Responsible Institutions: MCTES, sectoral ministries, academia, private sector, and civil society organisations Timeframe: 2025-2026

recommendations.title: Establish a governance structure for AI regulation
recommendations.text: Establish a governance structure for AI regulation: • A comprehensive framework should be developed that includes legal, ethical, and technical guidelines, ensuring responsible development, deployment, and usage of AI. This structure encompasses regulatory bodies, standards, and oversight mechanisms to address issues such as data privacy, algorithmic transparency, accountability, and fairness, providing a robust foundation for the ethical and effective integration of AI in various sectors within the country. Responsible Institutions: MCTES, sectoral ministries, academia, private sector, and civil society organisations Timeframe: 2025-2026

recommendations.title: Establish a Data Protection Agency
recommendations.text: Establish a Data Protection Agency: A dedicated regulatory body with the authority to enforce and oversee data protection laws is needed to ensure responsible handling, processing, and safeguarding of personal information. This agency would play a crucial role in setting standards, investigating data breaches, and promoting a privacy-conscious culture, contributing to the protection of individuals’ rights in the digital landscape and fostering trust in data-driven technologies across the nation.

recommendations.title: Responsible Institutions
recommendations.text: Responsible Institutions: MCTES, sectoral ministries Timeframe: 2025-2027 Enhance the gathering of data and statistics concerning the utilization of AI: Robust data and reliable statistics are essential for advancing ethical practices, as they enable comprehensive understanding of how AI technologies are employed across various sectors. This enhanced data collection fosters transparency, accountability, and informed decision-making, providing valuable insights into the ethical implications, societal impact, and potential biases associated with AI applications. These efforts can be accomplished by a new data regulator working in tandem with the National Statistics Bureau.

recommendations.title: Responsible Institutions
recommendations.text: Responsible Institutions: MCTES, sectoral ministries, INTIC, National Communications Institute of Mozambique (INCM), Institute of Electronic Government (INAGE), National Statistics Institute (INE) Timeframe: 2025-2027 Develop AI strategies: Deliberate planning and implementation of comprehensive frameworks should be conducted to guide the development, deployment, and ethical use of AI. This strategic approach encompasses defining clear objectives, fostering innovation, and addressing ethical considerations to harness the transformative potential of AI for societal benefit, economic growth, and the advancement of Mozambique’s unique sociocultural context.

recommendations.title: Promote skills training in AI
recommendations.text: Promote skills training in AI: • School curricula should be revised to include components of computational thinking, critical thinking, programming, AI, and ethics from an early age. A complete review process is needed that not only identifies curriculum components that need to 37 be changed or added but also creates a plan for updating and providing teacher training to accommodate these changes. Responsible Institutions: MCTES, sectoral ministries Timeframe: 2025-2027

recommendations.title: Reduce digital gender divides
recommendations.text: Reduce digital gender divides: • Concerted efforts will be needed to diminish disparities in opportunities and representation between genders. This involves implementing policies, educational initiatives, and awareness campaigns to create an inclusive environment that empowers women, addresses gender biases, and ensures equal participation and access to resources in all aspects of society, including the rapidly evolving field of AI. Responsible Institutions: MCTES, sectoral ministries Timeframe: 2025-2027

recommendations.title: Evaluate the impact of AI and automation on the workforce
recommendations.text: Evaluate the impact of AI and automation on the workforce: • A comprehensive examination should be conducted to understand how advancements in AI and automation affect employment, skills, and job dynamics. This evaluation aims to identify opportunities and challenges, inform strategic workforce planning, and guide the implementation of policies that promote a balanced integration of AI, ensuring that benefits are maximized and potential adverse effects on employment and the overall labour market are mitigated. Responsible Institutions: MCTES, sectoral ministries Timeframe: 2025-2027

recommendations.title: Strengthen the ability to guarantee intellectual property and copyright
recommendations.text: Strengthen the ability to guarantee intellectual property and copyright: • In the age of AI, fortifying the assurance of intellectual property and copyright demands a holistic strategy. Regulatory frameworks must dynamically adapt to technological shifts, delineating precise guidelines for the creation, ownership, and utilization of AI-generated content. Collaborative efforts between legal experts, tech innovators, and policymakers are indispensable in crafting nuanced legislation. Moreover, integrating AI itself is pivotal—implementing sophisticated algorithms for content tracking and authentication can effectively identify and safeguard intellectual property. Education and awareness initiatives play an equally crucial role in enlightening creators and users about the nuances of AI-generated content and cultivating a culture that respects intellectual property rights. In addition, international cooperation and global engagement are important factors. Responsible Institutions: MCTES, Ministry of Tourism and Culture, sectoral ministries, civil society organisations Timeframe: 2025-2027 Dimension Recommendation Timeframe Priority

keyFindings: Namibia is actively working to implement the UNESCO framework on ethics of AI and the establishment of a National Responsible AI Institute as recommended by the 4IR Taskforce Report, is a central proposal for coordinating future AI development.

Additionally, Namibia is also advancing foundational work in data governance, through the development of a Data Protection Bill, making strides in data openness with initiatives like the National Statistics Agency (NSA) open data portal, and enhancing digital skills through its draft National Digital Strategy and e-government initiatives such as e-health, e-government procurement and the Namibia Cybersecurity Strategy.

The report concludes that while progress is being made, further efforts are needed in policy development, capacity building, and infrastructure improvement to fully harness AI’s potential for national development.
The Constitution of Namibia mandates the government to promote economic growth, prosperity, and dignity for all citizens, with a strong emphasis on science and technology development.
Namibia’s Vision 2030 highlights the essential role of ICT in transitioning the country into a knowledge-based, industrialized, and eco-friendly society.

keyFindings: Since 2019, the Dutch government has invested considerable efforts into AI.
An initiative aimed at increasing transparency about the use of AI and algorithms is the Dutchalgorithm registryfor the public sector, which was launched at the end of 2022.
Ethics and trustare central to the AI discourse in the Netherlands.
The Netherlands also has significantjudicial expertisewhen it comes to AI and international law. This also provides a possibilities for specialization in supervisory roles and arbitration.

The Dutch government developed theFundamental Rights and Algorithms Impact Assessment(FRAIA), which helps to map the risks to fundamental rights in the use of algorithms and to take measures to address this.

recommendations.text: Under the AI Act, several sectoral exclusions are stipulated (defence and military, national security, scientific research and development). Some sectors come with specific provisions (law enforcement, public security, and open-source development). The exclusions are, for example, for national security, “justified both by the fact that national security remains the sole responsibility of Member States in accordance with Article 4(2) TEU and by the specific nature and operational needs of national security activities and specific national rules applicable to those activities” (AI Act, 2024,

recommendations.title: Article 24). It is worthy to note that the exclusion does not apply to dual-use technologies (i.e. those also used outside
recommendations.text: Article 24). It is worthy to note that the exclusion does not apply to dual-use technologies (i.e. those also used outside of the national security context) and that there is no clear definition of national security provided. The exclusions were debated extensively, both during the negotiation phase of the AI Act and by human rights groups.210 The Netherlands’ Stakeholder Team also highlighted caveats and potential weaknesses caused by the exclusions. Stakeholders mentioned the lack of clarity on the scope of national security, the potentially blurry lines between national and public security, and the high-stakes at hand which need to be assessed on a case-by-case basis to meet the requirements of the European Charter of Fundamental Rights.211 The stakeholders argued that the Netherlands must clearly delineate how to address the use of AI under the exclusions of the AI Act and take a leadership position on the topic of human rights. Government response The Dutch government acknowledges the exception in the European AI Act for among others national security, military or defence purposes. However, the Dutch government emphasises the need for the responsible and lawful use of AI. 210 Refer to the joint analysis of leading digital, human rights and social justice groups entitled EU’s AI Act fails to set gold standard for human rights (2024). Amongst others, contributors include representatives from Amnesty International, Algorithm Watch, and Bits of Freedom 211 Powell, R. (2024). The Dutch Intelligence and Security Services Act 2017 (Wet op de inlichtingen- en veiligheidsdiensten (Wiv) 2017) governs the lawful use of automated data-analysis, which includes algorithms and AI, by the Dutch General Intelligence and Security Service (Algemene Inlichtingen en Veiligheidsdienst, AIVD). The Wiv 2017 contains an explicit legal prohibition on promoting or taking measures against a person solely on the basis of results of automated data analysis. In all cases, there will be a human assessment. Furthermore, the law states that the processing of personal data solely on the grounds of a person's religion or belief, race, trade union membership, health and sexual life is not permitted. During the period of 2024–2026, the Dutch disarmament ambassador serves as Chair of the GGE LAWS. A central topic of discussion within the GGE LAWS is the application of international law, particularly international humanitarian law. The Netherlands often emphasizes the significance of international human rights law as a relevant legal framework for the potential development, deployment and use of weapon systems with autonomous capabilities and advocates for the inclusion of this topic in international discussions. Notably, the human rights legal framework imposes more stringent requirements on the use of deadly force in law enforcement contexts compared to the provisions of international humanitarian law governing combat operations. recommendations.text: Consider sovereignty on all layers of the technology stack in order to develop targeted efforts that increase competitiveness and reduce dependencies In spite of significant regulatory efforts and governance initiatives on AI, the Netherlands’ Stakeholder Group suggested that efforts should take into consideration all layers of the technology stack model (Figure 0.1) in order to have an overarching approach to digital open strategic autonomy.217 Digital sovereignty leads to agency in deciding the norms and values that AI tools should abide by. While the impact of AI is currently addressed on an infrastructural and technological level, more attention should go towards the application layer upon which digital platforms operate. In many different sectors such as education, digital platforms of Big Tech companies are pushing out smaller players in the national market, leading to dependencies and vendor lock-ins, privacy issues and market deterioration.

recommendations.title: Digital sovereignty is an important topic for the Dutch government. In 2023, the Agenda on Digital Open Strategic
recommendations.text: Digital sovereignty is an important topic for the Dutch government. In 2023, the Agenda on Digital Open Strategic Autonomy (DOSA) was published.220 This agenda recognizes the increasing dependency on third countries for our digital technologies. The agenda has six stack levels: resources, hardware, physical infrastructure, soft infrastructure, data, and applications and services. On the basis of these stack levels, the agenda identifies several specific policy priorities: critical raw materials, quantum technology, photonics, semiconductors, network technology, open-source software, cloud, AI, cybersecurity, and office software. It also identifies more general priorities, such as competitiveness, effective policy and decision making, security policy, knowledge and skills, and international cooperation. With each priority, current and new (policy) initiatives are announced on the national and the EU level. In general, the Netherlands tries to keep digital sovereignty and open strategic autonomy on the EU-agenda, which is in line with the portfolio of the new EU Commissioner on Tech Sovereignty, Security and Democracy in 2024-2029, Ms. Henna Virkkunen. In the education sector, specific attention is directed at the implications of the EU Data Act and the Digital Services Act among others, on primary education and the digital applications used in it. recommendations.text: Without mechanisms to make these processes more inclusive and accessible, such as public consultations, educational campaigns, or citizen assemblies on AI, there is a risk that AI policies will not adequately reflect the diverse concerns, values, and needs of Dutch society. This issue becomes of particular relevance in the case of AI being used for algorithmic-decision making.224 In response, the Stakeholder Team advised to formally integrate civic engagement programs and initiatives in the policy-making process around AI. Government response The Dutch government acknowledges the need to encourage social dialogue and cooperation at various levels in order to be able to respond to the fundamental challenges that AI poses. Ensuring safe and responsible development, use, and integration of AI, as well as maximizing the opportunities that AI offers, requires a coordinated effort from all levels of government, the private sector, technical community, academia and civil society. Together with local governments and implementation organizations, the Netherlands is exploring ways in which AI can support in making communication with citizens clearer and more inclusive. The vision on generative AI has been developed in close collaboration with all levels of government (including organisations responsible for implementing policies), businesses from several domains and sectors, academia and civil society. This cooperation remains essential in the future as well. This means actively involving several actors such as civilians, policy-makers from all levels of government, employers, businesses, entrepreneurs, scientists, employees and educators. It is essential that various actors have a voice in shaping the future where generative AI plays a role. The Dutch AI Coalition played a crucial role in fostering social dialogue, for example through the AI-Parade. recommendations.text: Even before the sudden surge of interest in generative AI, scientists had already flagged the considerable carbon footprint of AI. It is important to acknowledge that AI is destined to play a dual role. On the one hand, it can help to reduce the effects of the climate crisis – from optimising our energy grid to developing low-emission infrastructures.

recommendations.text: Yet, on the other hand, the carbon footprint of training AI models is considerable.231 Today, the “environmental impacts are expected to escalate considerably, with the global AI energy demand projected to exponentially increase to at least 10 times the current level and exceed the annual electricity consumption of a country like Belgium by 2026”.232 In addition to the high degree of carbon emissions and electricity use, AI is also associated with substantial water consumption, ‘both directly for onsite server cooling and indirectly for offsite electricity generation’.233 In response, the Netherlands’ Stakeholder Team have recommended to define best-practices related to sustainability and environmental considerations in the development and use of AI (ideally, beyond the requirements stipulated in the AI Act). recommendations.text: Thirdly, AI is developing at such a rapid and disruptive pace that it is necessary to look for new ways to translate knowledge and research into effective policy and to connect researchers with policymakers and the parliament. The government has worked on and continues to work on ways to address this issue through the development of a ‘Science for policy’ approach. Policies developed solely on the basis of scientific knowledge are ‘evidence-based’; ‘evidence- informed’ policy is developed when scientific knowledge is combined with practical knowledge.240 The ‘science for policy’ approach is an important tool to not only stay up-to-date on AI developments, but also to bridge the gap between policy and research in general. This is also supported by the EU platform ‘Knowledge4Policy’ which provides a high-quality research database that can be used by policymakers.241 The new European Commission has announced to strengthen the uptake of AI in research at European level, by setting up a European AI Research Council. recommendations.text: Prioritise in the expansion of assessments and labs for responsible development of AI and in the producing of new (general) tools The Netherlands’ Stakeholder Team flagged a discrepancy between the tools and assessments for the ethical / responsible / transparent development of AI and practice. Academics are well aware of the problematics with the panoply of existing guidelines, and the gap between ethics and practice. In a recent literature study, it was flagged that ethics in the context of AI guidelines is frequently not defined and rather vague, therefore making the application challenging at best, and contested at worst.242 Guidelines often lack agreement, both in terms of what the most important principles are and what their solutions are.243 As a result, one may observe a “gulf between ethical guidelines and practical implementation, a gap between principles and practice” that may maintain the status quo and an undesired outcome “business as usual”.244

Clear national, European (or international) frameworks can contribute to accelerating innovation. The European AI Act provides a solid foundation in this respect. recommendations.title: Act, the Netherlands is in the process of establishing regulatory sandboxes. With these sandboxes, supervisory
recommendations.text: Act, the Netherlands is in the process of establishing regulatory sandboxes. With these sandboxes, supervisory authorities enter into a regulatory dialogue with participants to assist them with AI Act related questions on the development, testing or validation of (high risk) AI systems. Such measures will help increase legal certainty, thereby stimulating innovation, and increasing the development and use of responsible and safe AI. As for the public sector, in recent years, the Dutch government has provided policy aimed at the responsible development and use of algorithms and AI by government bodies, as well as fostering innovation of such technology. As mentioned in previous chapters, tools to help foster the responsible use of AI in the public sector include a fundamental rights and algorithms impact assessment for the early mapping of risks to fundamental rights in the use of algorithms and AI. To address the ‘panoply’ of guidelines and regulations, the Dutch government published an algorithm framework in 2024.245 This framework provides an overview of applicable laws and regulations, provides practical tools and measures to take to comply with laws and regulations, as well as examples and use cases.

recommendations.title: Digital literacy in marginalized communities remains a critical area for policy improvement, particularly in the age of
recommendations.text: Digital literacy in marginalized communities remains a critical area for policy improvement, particularly in the age of AI, where divides can exacerbate existing inequalities.257 As AI-driven technologies become increasingly embedded in education, healthcare, and employment, those lacking basic digital skills are at a greater disadvantage.258 For marginalized groups, limited access to digital infrastructure and literacy means they miss out on opportunities to leverage tools that can enhance learning, job prospects, and access to services. Without targeted policies to improve digital literacy and ensure equitable access to AI technologies, these communities risk being left further behind in a rapidly evolving digital economy. Addressing this gap is essential for ensuring that AI benefits are distributed inclusively, empowering all sectors of society and creating a stronger societal support base for the digital economy. The Netherlands’ Stakeholder Team flagged that digital literacy in the context of marginalized communities remains a policy area for improvement.259 In response, the stakeholders recommended to develop capacities to design policy that addresses digital literacy throughout all layers of society. To do so, civic engagement and the participation of civil society in policy making was proposed as valuable method to follow. 250 Kabinet presenteert visie op generatieve AI | Nieuwsbericht | Rijksoverheid.nl 251 Regeerprogramma (overheid.nl), page 122. 252 Commission launches AI innovation package (europa.eu) 253 EU competitiveness: Looking ahead - European Commission (europa.eu) 254 e6cd4328-673c-4e7a-8683-f63ffb2cf648_en (europa.eu) 255 Motie van het lid Kathmann (16/01/2025). 256 Kamerbrief verkenning mogelijkheden AI-faciliteit | Kamerstuk | Rijksoverheid.nl; Motie van het lid Kathmann (16/01/2025); Motie van het lid Vermeer (16/01/2025). 257 This was particularly recognized in the context of generative AI (Hendawy, 2024). 258 Gonzales, S. recommendations.title: Technological developments, such as the development of generative AI, increase the production and dissemination of
recommendations.text: Technological developments, such as the development of generative AI, increase the production and dissemination of disinformation. Distinguishing between reliable, objective and factual news and disinformation is becoming increasingly confusing. In addition, AI technology can facilitate microtargeting, posing risks both to privacy and personal autonomy. This necessitates further efforts to increase media literacy among various target groups in order to prevent less digitally adept people from falling behind as well as protecting them from potentially negative effects of AI. In the Netherlands, the Dutch Network on Media Literacy helps foster media literacy among Dutch society, focussing on both resilience against risks and the opportunities AI offers. In the entire educational system, skills such as critical and structured thinking are becoming increasingly necessary. In this context, the reform of the curriculum for primary and secondary education is important. The new core educational objective on digital literacy as recently launched for primary and secondary education, considers four domains: 1) practical ICT skills, 2) media literacy, 3) digital information skills, 4) computational thinking. Students will acquire knowledge about digital technology, learn how to collaborate with them in a critical and (self)conscious manner, and assess the opportunities and risks involved in using them, which is all very relevant for AI. The AI Act lists a number of factors that weigh in when promoting AI literacy, but these need further fleshing out to provide sufficient guidance. In the context, the Dutch privacy authority has published a short guide to promote AI literacy within organizations that develop AI-systems.260 The Dutch government has an active policy to address disinformation and fake news, taking into account new possibilities based on AI. In its letter of 17 June 2024 it has reported its progress to Dutch parliament.261 Promoting media literacy of Dutch citizens

recommendations.title: December 2024, the Netherlands has addressed the theme of better regulation in the digital domain and proposed
recommendations.text: December 2024, the Netherlands has addressed the theme of better regulation in the digital domain and proposed to particularly discuss the burden for SMEs in next Council meetings. The Netherlands has also welcomed the announcement by the European Commission to prioritise an assessment that would identify whether the digital acquis – all agreed EU regulation in the digital domain - reflect the needs of SMEs. The Dutch government has called upon the European Commission to strictly enforce the evaluation clauses of the legislation under the digital rulebook.265 Additionally, the Dutch government has spoken out in favour of a review of the entire digital rulebook as a whole when all laws have been implemented. Through such a review, the effectiveness and interplay of the legislation can be mapped and improved. The Dutch government is working on establishing regulatory sandboxes for the AI Act. In 2024, a pilot was conducted to gather information on the practical aspects of operating a sandbox and to receive input from stakeholders. An important aspect of the AI Act sandbox is ‘regulatory learning’. According to this principle, the insights and learned lessons from regulatory sandboxes on the application of the AI Act should be shared broadly within the AI-ecosystem and with policy makers. An important point of attention for the Dutch government in the further implementation is how regulatory sandboxes can contribute to harmonised application of the AI Act.

recommendations.title: Developing and retaining talent in the Netherlands is also a matter of ensuring diversity and inclusion, which is not yet
recommendations.text: Developing and retaining talent in the Netherlands is also a matter of ensuring diversity and inclusion, which is not yet fully integrated into the country's AI sector. Although the Netherlands is known for its open, multicultural society, there is still work to be done in creating diverse teams that represent a variety of backgrounds, perspectives, and experiences. This diversity is essential for addressing biases in AI models and ensuring that the technology benefits all sectors of society266. Furthermore, building inclusive talent pipelines that encourage participation from women, minorities, and underrepresented groups will be critical to both the ethical and practical development of AI technologies. The Dutch government and institutions have acknowledged this challenge and yet, the Stakeholder Team has advised for more deliberate efforts to integrate these diverse perspectives into AI development. To attract and nurture talent, the Netherlands could enhance its international collaborations to foster a more orchestrated effort in knowledge exchange. Dutch universities and research institutions already have strong ties to

recommendations.title: European and global partners267, but there is room for more structured and frequent exchanges of expertise.
recommendations.text: European and global partners267, but there is room for more structured and frequent exchanges of expertise. Strengthening collaborations with other hubs internationally and other parts of Europe can help the Netherlands remain at the forefront of AI advancements. Such exchanges—whether through academic partnerships, joint research initiatives, or cross-border innovation projects—will allow practitioners to continuously update their skills, learn from global best practices, and contribute to a shared global vision for AI development. In reflection to these observations, it was recommended that the Netherlands develop a coherent and unified strategy to retain and attract talent around AI. This ought to include plans on attracting foreign talent (both technical and non- technical), plans on diversity and inclusion, as well as knowledge exchanges. Government response The Dutch government is committed to developing and retaining AI talent, so that we can develop (generative) AI that meets European norms and values. This is also of added value for the digital open strategic autonomy of Europe.

keyFindings: Peru has made early and significant normative advances in AI governance, positioning itself as one of the first countries in the region to adopt a general-scope AI law.
Building on this strong normative momentum, the report identifies an opportunity to further consolidate implementation and institutional alignment.
From an ecosystem perspective, Peru faces challenges in articulating a mature and sustainable AI ecosystem.
Human capital development and digital literacy emerge as cross-cutting priorities.
Finally, Peru shows comparatively strong performance in digital infrastructure at the regional level, ranking above the Latin American average in international benchmarks.

recommendations.title: Establish a National Framework for Data Sharing and Trusted Data Pooling
recommendations.text: Establish a National Framework for Data Sharing and Trusted Data Pooling Thailand should stablish a clear legal framework to support data sharing and create trusted data pooling between the public and private sectors. Government agencies should lead by providing high-quality open government data in standardized, machine-readable formats to enhance accessibility for AI training and research. The framework must prioritize the reuse of non-personal and anonymized datasets under strong privacy and ethical safeguards. Beyond the public sector, data-sharing mechanisms should be established to encourage private sector participation through incentive structures and risk-governance model that balance competitive interests with the protection of individual rights. Strategic prioritization of high-value datasets, driven my user demand, will help lay the foundation for ethical, resilient, and socially beneficial AI development in Thailand. Timeline: 2025-2026 Priority: High 67

recommendations.title: Strengthen Legal Safeguards for Human Rights and Algorithmic Accountability
recommendations.text: Strengthen Legal Safeguards for Human Rights and Algorithmic Accountability To promote fair and transparent AI governance, the Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA) should be enhanced to guarantee the rights of individuals to object to automated decision-making and profiling where such processing significantly impacts their rights or access to services. Given that AI systems often rely on personal data to make predictions or decisions, clear legal pathways for objections are essential to safeguard individual autonomy and build public trust. Additionally, individuals should be able to challenge and appeal automated outcomes that significantly affect them, especially when they affect critical areas such as public services, credit, employment, or education. These rights would strengthen public accountability and ensure that AI systems respect fairness, transparency, and due process. Enhancing these legal safeguards would help bridge current regulatory gaps and reinforce trust in AI-driven decision-making. Timeline: 2025–2030 Priority: Low

recommendations.title: Establish Risk Assessment Framework
recommendations.text: Establish Risk Assessment Framework Thailand should develop a national risk assessment framework to systematically identify, evaluate, and mitigate the potential harms associated with AI systems, particularly those classified as high-risk. This framework should outline clear criteria for assessing AI risks to fundamental rights, safety, fairness, and transparency, and offer practical tools for both public and private sector developers to evaluate their systems throughout the AI lifecycle. The framework should initially focus on high-impact or high-risk use cases, such as AI systems used in healthcare, law enforcement, finance, education, and critical public services—where errors, bias, or lack of oversight could result in significant harm to individuals or society. For high-risk AI systems, policymakers should also consider requiring insurance or liability coverage schemes to ensure adequate compensation in cases of harm, especially when legal responsibility cannot be clearly assigned. While the framework should not impose unnecessary regulatory burdens on low-risk innovation, it should strongly encourage risk-based self-assessment, documentation, and transparency practices for any AI system that affects human decision-making or public trust. The framework can be integrated into existing regulatory sandboxes, procurement processes, or audit mechanisms to ensure responsible AI deployment. Timeline: 2025-2026 Priority: High

recommendations.title: Establish AI procurement guideline
recommendations.text: Establish AI procurement guideline Thailand has set up a special committee to oversee government procurement of computer systems, requiring agencies to obtain approval for projects exceeding 100 million baht. However, the committee’s considerations focus only on technical feasibility and financial efficiency, while neglecting the ethical implications and potential impacts of AI on human rights. This guideline could assist agencies in evaluating their AI needs by providing clear instructions and recommendations for acquiring AI systems. It can also emphasize the importance of ethical considerations in the procurement process aligning with UNESCO’s Ethical Impact Assessment, ensuring a responsible evaluation of suppliers and the adoption of AI technologies that serve the public’s best interests. recommendations.title: Develop Thailand’s National AI Strategy Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) mechanism
recommendations.text: Develop Thailand’s National AI Strategy Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) mechanism The achievements of Thailand’s National AI Strategy and Action Plan (2022–2027) are outlined in the National AI Strategy Annual Report. Even though the National AI Strategy’s annual report provides a broad overview of each strategy achievement. It does not specify more details about the plan’s evaluations, limitations, or challenges in the implementation phase. As a result, the annual report does not serve as an effective measure for assessing the plan’s implementation. To effectively assess the implementation of the plan, adopting a Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) mechanism is essential. M&E is a systematic process that enables organizations to measure the performance, effectiveness, and impact of programs, projects, or policies. Monitoring ensures activities align with objectives, identifying inefficiencies and delays, while evaluation provides deeper analysis of relevance, efficiency, and outcomes to determine whether goals have been achieved.142 A robust M&E framework typically includes key performance indicators (KPIs), data collection methods, reporting structures, and feedback loops, supporting informed decision-making and continuous improvement.143 It enhances transparency, accountability, and strategic planning, ensuring initiatives remain effective and aligned with their intended purpose.144 Thailand should establish an M&E mechanism to assess the effectiveness of the National AI Strategy, ensuring that its implementation is data-driven and results-oriented. This would provide a structured approach to evaluating real performance, optimizing resources, and maintaining efficiency and accountability. The National AI Committee could serve as the primary agency responsible for M&E, overseeing execution and driving the strategy forward while ensuring its alignment with national objectives. Timeline: 2025-2026 Priority: High 69

recommendations.title: Strengthen Thailand’s Existing NQI for AI and Establish a Dedicated AI Testing Infrastructure
recommendations.text: Strengthen Thailand’s Existing NQI for AI and Establish a Dedicated AI Testing Infrastructure Thailand already has the foundational elements of a National Quality Infrastructure (NQI)—including metrology, standardization, accreditation, and conformity assessment bodies—but these systems are not yet fully prepared to support the unique demands of AI technologies. To ensure AI systems developed or deployed in Thailand are safe, trustworthy, and internationally interoperable, the country must urgently adapt its NQI to be AI-ready and simultaneously establish a dedicated infrastructure for AI testing. This involves: • Upgrading Accreditation Systems: Ensure that existing accreditation mechanisms are capable of certifying laboratories and conformity assessment bodies (CABs) specifically for AI-related evaluations, including fairness, explainability, and robustness testing. • Expanding CAB Capabilities: Promote the development and recognition of Thai CABs that can perform AI-specific conformity assessments, covering both algorithmic behavior and data governance. • Adapting Metrology and Standardization: Equip Thailand’s national metrology and standardization systems with the tools and expertise to measure and validate AI-specific indicators, including performance benchmarking and probabilistic outputs. • Establishing AI Testing Facilities: Build dedicated infrastructure for AI system testing. These facilities would simulate real-world conditions and evaluate AI systems prior to deployment, especially in high-risk sectors like healthcare, mobility, and public administration. • Market Surveillance for AI: Leverage existing market surveillance mechanisms and adapt them for continuous monitoring of AI systems post-deployment, to detect systemic risks or violations of standards. recommendations.title: Establish National-level AI Governance and Promote International Cooperation
recommendations.text: Establish National-level AI Governance and Promote International Cooperation Thailand should explore the establishment of a dedicated AI Governance and Policy Center, leveraging existing expertise within the Electronic Transactions Development Agency (ETDA). Over time, this center could evolve into a UNESCO Category 2 Center (C2C), serving as a regional hub for ethical AI implementation, policy development, and capacity building in ASEAN and aligned with UNESCO’s Recommendation on the Ethics of AI. For international cooperation, such Centre can be associated with the UNESCO Global Observatory on the Ethics of AI. The C2C model would further position Thailand as an active contributor to South-South knowledge exchange and inclusive AI governance, enhancing the country’s influence in regional and global dialogues on responsible AI through international cooperation. Timeline: 2025–2026 Priority: High 70

recommendations.text: Integrate AI Literacy and Ethics into the National Education Curriculum (K to 12 or Higher Education), including teacher training and certification program Thailand has made initial progress in integrating AI and related subjects into the national education system, particularly through efforts by the Ministry of Education and the MHESI. Current initiatives mainly focus on technical competencies such as programming, data science, and machine learning. However, ethical, societal, and governance aspects of AI remain significantly underrepresented in curricula, and early assessments indicate a persistent skills gap, particularly in aligning education outcomes with labor market demands. Coordination between educational institutions and industry also remains limited. To build a comprehensive and future-proof education system, it is critical to expand the curriculum across all levels— from K-12 to higher education—to systematically incorporate AI literacy, ethics, and responsible innovation. Students must not only learn how to build AI systems, but also understand how to design, deploy, and manage AI technologies in a safe, fair, and socially responsible manner. In this time of major technological revolution, the education system should be revisited along two parallel tracks, to actively foster youth’s intellectual immunity in the face of misinformation, disinformation, and technological solutionism: (i) integrating specific AI-focused contents that tackle all dimensions (technical and sociocultural); and (ii) enhancing the quality of the teaching and learning methods in the existing disciplines and subject matters that develop critical and creative thinking, such as humanities, social studies, and civic education. In parallel, teacher training and certification programs should be developed to equip educators with the skills needed to teach AI concepts effectively, including both technical and ethical dimensions. recommendations.title: Labor incentives and programs for upskilling and reskilling
recommendations.text: Labor incentives and programs for upskilling and reskilling As AI and digital technologies advance rapidly, Thailand’s workforce faces growing pressure to adapt. Many existing jobs are at risk of disruption, and new roles increasingly require digital literacy and AI-related competencies. While some upskilling and reskilling initiatives have been introduced by both public and private sectors, participation remains 71 uneven, especially among workers in informal employment or SMEs. Without stronger incentives, large segments of the workforce risk being left behind in the digital transition. To accelerate human capital development, the government should implement labor incentives that encourage upskilling and reskilling, especially in AI and digital domains. These could include tax deductions or subsidies for companies that invest in employee training, as well as stipends or learning credits for individuals who pursue certified courses. Special attention should be given to workers in vulnerable sectors to ensure equitable access. Public-private partnerships should also be leveraged to co-develop relevant training programs and platforms, creating a more inclusive and future-ready workforce. Timeline: 2025-2026 Priority: High

recommendations.title: Establish AI training course
recommendations.text: Establish AI training course Thailand is advancing digital skills through the DGA. Therefore, the DGA establishes the “Thailand Digital Government Academy (TDGA)” to provide training for government agencies, collaborating with the Office of the Civil Service Commission (OCSC) to develop a digital skills curriculum for public employees. However, the TDGA’s courses are exclusively available to IT staff, not to all government employees. Additionally, the training overlooks topics related to AI governance and ethics. To enhance the skills and knowledge of government employees regarding AI, it is essential to develop an “AI training course.” This course should emphasize a comprehensive understanding of fundamental AI concepts, effective applications of AI within the public sector, and the importance of AI ethics and governance. Therefore, such a framework will empower government employees to view AI not just as a tool, but as a responsibility that requires thoughtful and ethical utilization. Timeline: 2025-2026 Priority: High

recommendations.title: Ensure Universal Design and Accessibility Standards
recommendations.text: Ensure Universal Design and Accessibility Standards Despite Thailand’s commitment to digital inclusion, AI-powered government portals and health applications frequently remain inaccessible to older adults, persons with disabilities, and low-literacy users. Current development contracts seldom embed rigorous accessibility requirements, and end-users report difficulty in navigating essential services— undermining trust in e-government initiatives and perpetuating exclusion. To rectify this, Thailand should encourage Universal Design Principles within all AI and digital-service procurement processes. Accessibility criteria, covering screen-reader compatibility, simplified interfaces, and multilingual support, should be included in the procurement criteria of public AI. Such a framework will ensure that technological innovation advances equitably, empowering all citizens to engage fully with public services. Timeline: 2025–2028 Priority: Medium

recommendations.title: Enhancing Digital Literacy and AI Competencies for Vulnerable Groups
recommendations.text: Enhancing Digital Literacy and AI Competencies for Vulnerable Groups Although rural broadband expansion has markedly improved connectivity, significant digital-skill gaps persist among seniors, low-income households, and ethnic-minority communities. Without targeted training, these groups struggle to leverage e-health platforms, e-government portals, and digital financial services, thereby exacerbating socioeconomic vulnerabilities. To address these disparities and build both AI and digital capabilities, Thailand should establish Boot Camps—offering hands-on workshops in AI-driven tools (e.g., voice assistants, mobile banking) alongside digital-safety training, particularly in rural areas where elderly and low-income populations have limited access to technology. Timeline: 2025–2026 Priority: High

recommendations.title: Preserve Cultural and Linguistic Diversity through AI initiatives
recommendations.text: Preserve Cultural and Linguistic Diversity through AI initiatives Thailand’s artificial intelligence (AI) ecosystem remains predominantly centered on Central Thai, marginalizing speakers of regional dialects and ethnic minority languages that lack extensive, annotated linguistic resources. This homogeneity restricts equitable access to natural language processing (NLP) technologies and endangers the preservation of cultural heritage and linguistic diversity. To redress this imbalance, the Thai government—working in partnership with local communities and academic institutions—should initiate a Dialectal Corpora Project. This effort would ethically collect, annotate, and curate speech and text datasets for regional dialects and hill-tribe languages, thereby enabling the creation of culturally authentic translation tools, educational platforms, and digital-heritage applications. By equipping AI systems to process the full spectrum of Thailand’s linguistic variation, the project will foster inclusive technological innovation and contribute to the long-term safeguarding of the nation’s rich linguistic heritage. Timeline: 2025–2030 Priority: Low 73

recommendations.title: Develop Community-Centric AI Co-Creation Platforms
recommendations.text: Develop Community-Centric AI Co-Creation Platforms Top-down AI deployments often fail to resonate with local realities, resulting in low adoption and inadequate problem- solving. Without direct community input, precision-agriculture tools or heritage-site guides risk being technically advanced yet socially irrelevant. Inspired by DEPA’s Smart City Ambassadors, Thailand should establish AI Co-Creation Hubs in both rural and urban locales. These labs will convene residents, SMEs, NGOs, and academic researchers for hackathons, user-testing workshops, and ethics dialogues—co-designing AI solutions that reflect lived experiences. By integrating digital-human capability courses, these hubs will transform community members into active co-designers rather than passive recipients. Timeline: 2025–2028 Priority: Medium

recommendations.title: Establish a National AI Consultancy Support Program to assist businesses and SMEs in AI solution
recommendations.text: Establish a National AI Consultancy Support Program to assist businesses and SMEs in AI solution adoption, including funding for solution design and technical training To accelerate AI adoption among businesses and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), Thailand should establish a National AI Consultancy Support Program aimed at providing targeted assistance for solution design and technical training. This program would offer expert consulting services to identify AI use cases that align with business objectives and sector-specific needs. Additionally, it would facilitate the design of fit-for-purpose AI solutions that are tailored to industry-specific challenges and opportunities. To lower the barriers to adoption, the program would also provide grants, vouchers, and co-funding mechanisms to support consultancy, prototyping, and training activities, ensuring that businesses, particularly SMEs, can access the expertise and resources needed to effectively integrate AI technologies. The initiative is prioritized for 2025–2026 with a high priority status, reflecting its strategic importance in boosting digital competitiveness and economic resilience. Timeline: 2025 – 2026 Priority: High 74

recommendations.title: Encourage AI-related infrastructure investment
recommendations.text: Encourage AI-related infrastructure investment The government should collaborate with relevant financial institutions to alleviate external uncertainties for the private sector, particularly concerning changes in data-related policies that may affect the effectiveness of AI-focused hyperscale data centers. For example, regulations around data localization could limit the ability of investors to integrate data from international sources. This collaboration could include providing investor access to risk assessment services with incentives such as reduced insurance premiums. Additionally, beyond hyperscale data centers driven by global tech firms, Thailand should prioritize the development of smaller-scale data centers, such as edge and modular facilities, to enhance on-site analytical capacity, precision, and AI processing speed. This infrastructure could significantly improve user experience, supporting AI adoption in local areas, including smart cities. These data centers are designed to be energy-efficient, helping to reduce the costs of AI development across the country. Furthermore, the expansion of edge and modular data center investments should be strategically directed towards rural and provincial areas beyond major metropolitan zones, where current data infrastructure is predominantly concentrated. This shift would facilitate broader AI deployment, bridge the technology gap, and promote balanced technological development nationwide. Timeline: 2025 - 2026 Priority: High

recommendations.title: Strengthen Investments in Data Pooling
recommendations.text: Strengthen Investments in Data Pooling To enhance data-driven innovation and sectoral competitiveness, Thailand aims to strengthen investments in data pooling across 10 strategic sectors by building sectoral single dataspaces. This initiative is designed to encourage collective data sharing and aggregation, enabling participants to access richer datasets that improve analytics and AI capabilities. As part of this strategy, exclusive rights to access pooled data will be granted to private participants as an incentive, while developers will have affordable service fees to utilize the data for innovation and solution development. Additionally, the government will prioritize upgrading its datasets, particularly in critical areas such as geospatial and mobility data, to enhance the value and reliability of shared information. This upgrade is crucial for ensuring that public-private data sharing is both efficient and beneficial, supporting nationwide digital transformation. The initiative is scheduled for implementation between 2025 and 2027 and is considered a high priority due to its potential to accelerate Thailand’s digital economy and AI adoption. Timeline: 2025 - 2026 Priority: High

recommendations.title: Unlocking Green Energy for Sustainable Data Center Expansion
recommendations.text: Unlocking Green Energy for Sustainable Data Center Expansion A major barrier for expanding green and energy-efficient data centers in Thailand is the limited availability of renewable energy production. While global tech investors increasingly require green energy sources for their data centers, Thailand’s current renewable energy capacity remains insufficient to meet growing demand. To address this, the government should accelerate investments in solar, wind, and hydropower projects, focusing on scaling up production capacity. Initiatives such as Public-Private Partnerships (PPPs) and green energy bonds could be explored to fund large-scale renewable energy infrastructure. Furthermore, regulatory support is needed to open direct Power Purchase Agreements (Direct PPA) and enable Third Party Access (TPA) for electricity supply. Currently, private sector entities cannot directly supply power to data centers, 75 limiting renewable energy adoption. By allowing direct PPA and third-party grid access, clean energy producers could supply electricity directly to data centers, bypassing current regulatory constraints. This change would enable more sustainable data center expansion and facilitate broader AI deployment. Additionally, microgrids and distributed energy generation in rural areas should be supported to localize green power, enhancing the sustainability and reliability of energy supplies for edge and modular data centers across Thailand. Timeline: 2025 - 2026 Priority: High

recommendations.title: Elevate Thailand’s R&D Investment to 2.5 percent of GDP by 2030
recommendations.text: Elevate Thailand’s R&D Investment to 2.5 percent of GDP by 2030 According to UNCTAD, share of AI in frontier technology market in 2023 is at 7 percent, which projects to increase to 29 percent in ten years. The forecast represents the importance of increasing the size of the AI market as well as corporate and private sector R&D spending, to keep up with the global trend. Currently, Thailand ranked is not outstanding in Global Innovation Index (ranked by the World Intellectual Property Organization). In 2024, its rank in human capital and research is at 71 among 133 countries reflecting the low proportion of R&D spending on innovation development. However, the country has a high innovation output relative to its innovation input, reflecting efficient resource utilization and indicating a strong potential for Thailand’s research to thrive. Thailand’s current R&D expenditure at 1.21 percent of GDP in 2024 while the percentage share in GDP of R&D decreases from 2023, it shows a rising trend since 2013 indicating the upward trend of the R&D spending in the country. However, the proportion of R&D remains low, ranked 34 among 133 countries. To enhance its competitiveness and foster economic growth, Thailand should aim to increase its R&D spending to 2.5 percent of GDP by 2030, with a dedicated sub-allocation of 0.5–0.7 percent of GDP for AI-specific research and innovation. This target aligns with the OECD average and positions Thailand to better compete with other nations in the region. Thailand remains primarily an importer of AI technology, positioning itself more as a user than a developer. As such, increasing investment in AI R&D may initially appear counterintuitive. However, it is crucial that the country allocate research funding strategically to areas where it can add the most value.
